hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
gpt-4_1-mini_translation: Puali‘i died, and then Nāmakaokapāo‘o returned to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat food. At that time, ‘Ama‘u, a chief of all O‘ahu who lived at Waikīkī, was sitting. Someone came from Honouliuli all the way to Waikīkī while the chief was there. He said: “O chief! There is a small but very strong child. His father died, and his head was severed far out in the sea, in a very distant place, five miles distant. ‘Ama‘u heard that the child had strength and said, ‘I will kill him,’ but then he said, ‘I will not kill him; he has no strength.’ When he was speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard these words.”
gpt-4_1-mini_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
Puali‘i died, and then Nāmakaokapāo‘o returned to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat food. At that time, ‘Ama‘u, a chief of all O‘ahu who lived at Waikīkī, was sitting. Someone came from Honouliuli all the way to Waikīkī while the chief was there. He said: “O chief! There is a small but very strong child. His father died, and his head was severed far out in the sea, in a very distant place, five miles distant. ‘Ama‘u heard that the child had strength and said, ‘I will kill him,’ but then he said, ‘I will not kill him; he has no strength.’ When he was speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard these words.”
</translation>

<commentary>
• This paragraph marks a turning point in the narrative, introducing the death of Puali‘i and illustrating the immediate aftermath involving Nāmakaokapāo‘o and his mother, Pōka‘ī:
  – The statement that Nāmakaokapāo‘o “did not eat food” (ʻa‘ohe ‘ai) is significant; it may indicate a period of fasting, mourning, or a metaphorical state reflecting his transition or grief following Puali‘i’s death.
  – The close physical and emotional proximity between mother and son underscores familial bonds and the traditional Hawaiian concept of ‘ohana as a source of strength and continuity.

• The appearance of ‘Ama‘u, identified explicitly as a chief (“ali‘i no O‘ahu nei”) residing in Waikīkī, situates the story geographically and politically:
  – Waikīkī was historically an important royal and residential area on O‘ahu, reinforcing ‘Ama‘u’s high status.
  – The name ‘Ama‘u may carry symbolic meaning; although ‘ama‘u is a type of Hawaiian fern, in a chiefly context, it can connote resilience or a native connection to the land.

• The messenger arriving from Honouliuli (a remote lowland district in Waiawa valley area, known historically for agriculture and settlements) to Waikīkī to address the chief reflects traditional Hawaiian communication and politics:
  – The journey “mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī” highlights the interconnectedness of districts on O‘ahu and the respect for chiefly authority across regions.
  – The message he delivers is significant, announcing the death of a chief (Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s father) and the severing of his head “kiola ‘ia kona po‘o,” a traditional indication of defeat or death possibly by war or execution at sea—the ocean often being a liminal space of judgment or consequence in Hawaiian belief.

• The detail of “he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka lō‘ihi” (a very distant place, five miles away) symbolizes not only physical distance but may have allegorical meaning:
  – The emphasis on the remote location could underscore exile or the finality of the father’s fate, heightening the dramatic tension.
  – Number symbolism is present: “lima” (five) is often a sacred or significant number in Hawaiian numerology, possibly indicating completeness or change.

• ‘Ama‘u’s reaction to hearing of the child’s strength and his mixed declaration reveals complex chiefship dynamics:
  – Initially ‘Ama‘u intends to kill Nāmakaokapāo‘o (“make au iā ia”), a common motif of challenge or trial to a rival or potential heir.
  – Yet ‘Ama‘u retracts, saying “ʻa‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika” (‘I will not kill him; he has no strength’), indicating assessment or underestimation.
  – This ambivalence suggests the evolving reputation of Nāmakaokapāo‘o—physically small yet possessing remarkable power—challenging common notions of strength and leadership.

• The fact that Nāmakaokapāo‘o overhears this conversation “ua lohe nō ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ʻōlelo” stresses the importance of words and knowledge in Hawaiian culture:
  – Hearing words spoken in a chiefly setting implies fate or a call to action; it may serve as a catalyst for the protagonist’s forthcoming deeds.
  – This also reflects the oral and communal nature of Hawaiian storytelling, where knowledge gained in such moments guides future behavior.

• In the broader cultural and narrative framework:
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o symbolizes a new force arising from the lineage of a decapitated chief, tying into themes of regeneration, hidden strength, and the cyclical nature of life and death in Hawaiian cosmology.
  – The paragraph may foreshadow the protagonist’s overcoming of societal expectations and existing power structures, a common motif in ali‘i genealogies and heroic tales.

• Overall, this passage exemplifies traditional storytelling elements:
  – Inclusion of genealogical and geographic details serve to ground the story in place and lineage.
  – The interplay between spoken word and action reveals normative behaviors—chiefly rivalry, recognition of strength beyond physicality, and the significance of knowledge.
  – The narrative tension established here sets the stage for the unfolding drama around Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s identity and destiny.
</commentary>
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
